Award.AwardTitle: Understanding the Genomic Landscape: High Altitudes, Adaptation, and Population Structure

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award was provided as part of NSF's Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships (SPRF) program. The goal of the SPRF program is to prepare promising, early career doctoral-level scientists for scientific careers in academia, industry or private sector, and government. SPRF awards involve two years of training under the sponsorship of established scientists and encourage Postdoctoral Fellows to perform independent research. NSF seeks to promote the participation of scientists from all segments of the scientific community, including those from underrepresented groups, in its research programs and activities; the postdoctoral period is considered to be an important level of professional development in attaining this goal. Each Postdoctoral Fellow must address important scientific questions that advance their respective disciplinary fields. Over 140 million people live in high altitude zones around the world and are susceptible to chronic or temporary disorders related to low oxygen concentrations (hypoxia). Reproductive disorders exacerbated with hypoxia include preeclampsia, which complicates 2-10% of all pregnancies worldwide, causes nearly 40% of all premature births and is associated in 10-15% of maternal deaths. Previous research has shown that native Andean populations carry unique genetic variants conferring adaptation to high altitude hypoxia. Some of this genetic variation may also underlie susceptibility to preeclampsia, and therefore may influence human reproductive fitness. This investigation characterizes genetic structure and adaptation in native populations from the Peruvian Andes to understand the genetic factors influencing human reproduction in challenging environments. Characterizing underlying genetic diversity and population history is essential for the identification of functional genetic variants, therefore this work will examine how past demographic processes in the region have shaped the genomes of indigenous Peruvians. This project is conducted in collaboration between USA (Arizona State University, Stanford University), Mexico (National Laboratory of Genomics for Biodiversity), and Peru (Puno Regional Hospital) based research teams. A crucial benefit of this opportunity is to increase representation of Latinos in genomics, promote international collaborative research, strengthen genomics research capacity within Latin America and further education through training and outreach. The project is led by a postdoctoral researcher underrepresented in the SBE sciences, and further broadens participation of underrepresented groups in the sciences by training Latin American graduate students. The genetic data produced by this project will be freely available upon completion, contributing to lessen the underrepresentation of ethnically diverse populations in human genomics research.

The Peruvian Andes was home to multiple major civilization centers of the pre-contact Americas, and contemporary peoples in this region retain a large reservoir of Native American genomic diversity. Because they have evolved adaptations to the extreme conditions of high altitude hypoxia, understanding the ancestry and evolution of native Andeans can lead to discovery of genetic loci involved in human adaptation for successful reproduction in low-oxygen environments. Thus, this investigation examines fine-scale patterns of genetic diversity in native Andeans to: (1) characterize their demographic history, (2) identify candidate loci under natural selection, and (3) understand how genomic architecture and admixture influence preeclampsia susceptibility and reproductive fitness in a high altitude environment. Genotype data from 17 native populations from the coastal, highland and lowland Andes (N=170) will be generated and analyzed to characterize local patterns of genetic diversity. Additionally, existing genotype data from Andean families suffering from preeclamptic pregnancies in Puno, Peru (N=530) will be analyzed by mapping associations between genetic variants, ancestry and preeclampsia phenotype. Studying human groups with unique genetic adaptations facilitates identification of the primary genetic factors underlying complex phenotypes and gene function. This research examines Andean groups as a model to understand human physiology in hypoxic conditions. This natural experiment provides an excellent opportunity to understand the genetic factors influencing human reproductive fitness in challenging environments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Native Andean populations carry unique genetic variants conferring adaptation to high altitude hypoxia. Some of this genetic variation may also underlie susceptibility to preeclampsia, a pregnancy complication which is a leading cause of premature births and maternal deaths in high-altitude regions of Peru and other countries. To understand the genetic factors influencing preeclampsia at high altitudes, this investigation characterized patterns of genetic structure and adaptation in native populations across the Peruvian Andes and surrounding regions.

Through collaboration with international research teams based in Peru, Mexico, USA and Spain, we collected samples from 332 native Peruvians in 29 locations within the three major ecozones of Peru: the desert Pacific coast, the jungle lowlands and the Andean highlands. We generated high-density genotype data at over 400,000 positions across the genome for these samples. Analyses of these data identified differences in ancestry patterns between coastal, highland and jungle lowland populations. Specifically, we found varying proportions of recent European and African admixture across Peru, with the highest proportions of African ancestry occurring in coastal populations and self-identified Afro Peruvian communities. We also found some differentiation within the Native American ancestry component of Highland populations. This finding suggests that Andean populations are a large reservoir of pre-European contact genetic variation and thus may carry rare genetic variants underlying adaptation and functional traits.

 We also identified differences in adaptive genetic variation across populations from the three ecozones. In highland communities, we found signatures of selection in candidate genes involved with adaptation to high altitude hypoxia, as well as metabolic and cardiac function. In contrast, coastal populations showed signatures of selection in candidate genes involved with muscle tissue formation and lipid metabolism. Lastly, jungle lowland populations had signatures of adaptation in candidate genetic regions involved with immune function. By characterizing these diverse signatures of selection in Peruvians from varied ecological contexts, this study contributes to our understanding of how microevolution and adaptation drives the genetic and phenotypic changes underlying human-specific traits and within-population diversity.

 Lastly, to examine how this underlying genetic diversity influence preeclampsia in the Andes, we examined genetic variation among preeclamptic families in Puno, Peru, a high-altitude city nearly 4,000 meters above sea level. Working with researchers and clinicians from Peru, Mexico and the USA, we collected blood from 914 individuals in affected and control family trios (including maternal, paternal, and cord blood) at the Regional Hospital of Puno. We generated high-density genotype data at over 500,000 positions across the genome for this cohort. With these data we determined ancestry patterns and mapped associations between genetic variants and preeclampsia phenotype.  

We found no evidence of ancestry related susceptibility to preeclampsia in this cohort. But our analyses identified strong associations with several variants near genes involved with placental and blood vessel function, and therefore, of functional importance for human pregnancy biology. One such region includes a cluster of clotting factor genes on chromosome 13. This finding suggests that coagulation plays an important role in the pathology of preeclampsia and potentially underlies other pregnancy disorders exacerbated at altitude. 

Studying human groups with unique genetic adaptations facilitates identification of the primary genetic factors underlying complex phenotypes and gene function. This research examined Andean populations as a model to understand human physiology in hypoxic conditions. This natural experiment provides an excellent opportunity to understand the genetic factors influencing human reproductive fitness in challenging environments worldwide.

Our broader and long-term aims with this study were to inform future biomedical research and potential health interventions for at-risk Andean women. Affordable genetic screening platforms that incorporate the susceptibility variants identified here can be developed and deployed in the region to prevent undiagnosed cases that often result in female mortality due to late detection and treatment. Through this work we also increased representation of Latino/as in genomics, promoted international collaborative research, and strengthened genomics research capacity within Latin America. The data collection and analyses involved in the study were part of the postdoctoral training of the principal investigator, who is a female researcher from Puerto Rico, and thus a member of an underrepresented group in the sciences. This work also furthered education through training of graduate and undergraduate students from Mexico, Peru and the USA in laboratory and data analysis methods. Overall research results are currently being prepared for peer-review and project findings are being actively disseminated through presentations at international scientific meetings. Lastly, the deidentified genotype data produced from this study will be made freely available upon completion, contributing to lessen the underrepresentation of ethnically diverse populations in human genomics research.
